instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.ONOFF_L: What is ONOFF_L? This is a abbreviation of SMC_ONOFF_L.When you see ONOFF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
Corrosion to / around:
J5731, J5800, <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, VR5020


With Real 85W Charger - Voltages:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3V3V
PP3V42 = 3V42
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0

What tells the PCH to send out <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> please?
Anything obvious I should check too?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
Get green light on MagSafe?
Switch to amber when battery connected?
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>,
Also check PCH's RTC signals...

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
Green / Orange = Yes
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3V4
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = low / 0 - with / without batt
"<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>" ..... Do you mean <SIGNAL>S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> (s)?


Hold up. Just plugged battery and charger and after maybe 5 minutes it powers. It does this even on a fully powered battery. With MagSafe and battery it will power after being plugged for 5 minutes. This is an Apple charger 85Watt.
Power button is non responsive, will check if it pulls low.

Just ran wire from KB connector to <SIGNAL>ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and it's now powering.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
Check other 85w charger.
It must power up without battery.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
I just got this one from Amazon on Sat..... I'll have to order another as I sold my chargers with machines. You think it could be a fake?

The machine STAYS powered with just charger if I connect batt, power on and remove batt, but will not actually power on from cold with just charger. Any idea?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message: Yes you probably got a fake Chinese garbage charger. Go in About this Mac and see in the power section the wattage of the connected charger.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17450"]Yes you probably got a fake Chinese garbage charger. Go in About this Mac and see in the power section the wattage of the connected charger. [/QUOTE]

[B]AC Charger Information:[/B]

  Connected: Yes
  ID: 0x0aa1
  Wattage (W): 85
  Family: 0x0085
  Serial Number: 0x0002ee49
  Charging: Yes

It's not a box of air and it is powering an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> just fine.
Who knows, I need to buy more chargers anyway.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message: It's 85W so it should be ok. Is PPBUS present on the charger alone?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17491"]It's 85W so it should be ok. Is PPBUS present on the charger alone?[/QUOTE]

Yep, PPBUS = 8.4V

With the machine complete it powers, charges and runs perfectly fine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message: So we can mark this as solved?

threads.title: [SOLVED]No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 17515"]So we can mark this as solved?[/QUOTE]

Yes please.

Charger is bullshit, got Apple Logo, IDs as 85W Apple but will not power all boards with just charger... Only some.
